name: Abbeyknockmoy Cistercian Abbey
tagline: Founded by one of the most feared Kings in Ireland
significance: One of only four sites in Ireland housing rare tempera wall-paintings
foundedBy: Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair (King of Connaught)

description.short: Knockmoy Abbey, also known as The Monastery of the Hill of Victory, is a ruined Cistercian ecclesiastical complex founded in 1189 by the much-feared King of Connaught, Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair.
description.full: Knockmoy Abbey (Mainistir Chnoc Muaidhe in Irish), also known as The Monastery of the Hill of Victory (Monasterium Collis Victoriæ in Latin), is a ruined Cistercian ecclesiastical complex located on the northern bank of the Abbert River in north east County Galway. Founded in 1189/1190 by Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair (Charles 'Red Hand' O'Connor), the much-feared King of Connaught whose bloody reign lasted for thirty-six years, the abbey became a significant religious center. Following the death of his wife Mór Ní Briain in 1217/1218, the king was buried alongside her in the abbey on 27th May 1224, dressed in the habit of a Franciscan Greyfriar. The abbey is renowned for housing one of only four tempera wall-paintings in Ireland, a rare and precious artwork dating from the 15th century that once covered the entire north end of the chancel. These paintings were reproduced as engravings in Edward Ledwich's 'Antiquities of Ireland' in 1790 and displayed at the Dublin Exhibition in 1853.
description.history: The abbey was founded in 1189/1190 by Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair (1153-1224), King of Connaught, and settled by monks from its sister house of Boyle Abbey in County Roscommon. The abbey endured a turbulent history, being plundered by William De Burgo in 1202 and again in 1228. In 1240, the Abbot was censured for having his hair washed by a woman, and in 1483, the Abbot was accused of setting fire to the abbey. Following the dissolution of the monasteries in the 16th century, the Abbot-in-Commendam, Hugh O'Kelly, surrendered the abbey to King Henry VIII on 24th May 1542. O'Kelly was appointed as rent collector, and the abbey's church remained as the parish church, becoming known as Porta Magna (Great Door) and Teampollandorusmoir (The Chapel with the Big Door).
description.architecture: Although the majority of the buildings date from the early 13th century, there is evidence of additional building in both the 15th and 16th centuries. The monastery's church has a wide nave, a chancel, and narrow transepts to the north and south containing two side chapels. The rib-vaulted chancel features fine carved capitals and an east-facing window. A sculpted head of a king, possibly Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair, can be seen in the southwest corner of the church. Dormitories were located above both the vaulted-ceilinged sacristy and the chancel. The vaulted chapter room features an original three-light window with elaborately moulded jambs, as well as later two single-light windows. A calefactory (monks' day room) sits to the south of the chapter room, and there is a refectory at the south end of the church. The abbey ruins surround a cloister on its north, east and south sides.
description.culturalSignificance: Knockmoy Abbey is of exceptional cultural importance as one of only four sites in Ireland housing rare tempera wall-paintings. These 15th-century paintings are of very special significance and were weather-proofed by the Office of Public Works in the 1980s to protect these rare images. The abbey also contains a beautifully carved memorial plaque to Elevina Kirwan (dated 8th August 1684), the second wife of Robert French of Monivae, featuring her armorial bearing and the motto 'Laus Deo' (Praise be to God). The abbey served as the burial place of one of Ireland's most powerful medieval kings, Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair, adding to its historical importance.

directions.general: Located on the northern bank of the Abbert River in north east County Galway, 12.5 kilometres south east of the town of Tuam and one kilometre north east of the village of Abbeyknockmoy
directions.byCar: Car park is located a short walk away near the graveyard
directions.parking: Car park available (short walk to site)

seasonal.notes: Unguided site - accessible at all times

tourOptions.notes: No guided tours available - unguided site

visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: This is an unguided site and a level of care and caution should be maintained during all stages of your visit. Access requires going through a stile (over a fence via steps). Car park is located a short walk away near the graveyard. Appropriate footwear recommended for uneven surfaces. The Office of Public Works will not be held responsible for any damages, injuries, or losses that occur.

accessibility.notes: Challenging access - requires navigating a stile (over a fence via steps). Uneven surfaces throughout. Not suitable for wheelchairs or limited mobility.
